So Fatimah tore the curtain of the door and pulled the bracelets from the hands of her two children and cut them into pieces, then her two children cried, so she distributed them to the two children. Then they went to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) crying, then the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) took the things from them, saying, 'O Thauban, go and take these things to Bani Fulan and buy for Fatimah a necklace of shells and two bracelets of ivory, for indeed they are my family, and I do not want them to exhaust their good things during their life in this world.'" (Narrated by Ahmad and al-Baihaqi)

The meaning of this hadith is not to prohibit Muslims from wearing jewelry, liking beauty, enjoying the sustenance that Allah has bestowed, but rather to encourage people to live according to their own abilities, not excessively, always being considerate in living as neighbors and in being friends. Do not let the wealth that is owned legally become a source of envy and jealousy for neighbors and friends. Also, do not live extravagantly, and spend beyond your means. Always remember that many other people need help, there are still many expenses needed to elevate the word of Allah. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) always felt content when he obtained something and was patient when he had nothing; he ate cake if he could afford to buy it, drank honey if he happened to have it, ate meat if he could get it. Such things became his guide and habit of life. He always thanked Allah every time he received His blessings.

What is prohibited is wearing jewelry excessively, having fun without remembering the existence of eternal life in the Hereafter. Wearing jewelry without excess and without causing envy to others is permissible. Allah says:

Say, "Who has forbidden the adornment of Allah which He has produced for His servants and the good [lawful] things of provision?" Say, "They are for those who believe during the worldly life [but] exclusively for them on the Day of Resurrection." Thus do We detail the verses for a people who know. (al-A'raf/7: 32)
text.21:
Allah commanded the Messenger of Allah (saw) to convey to the polytheists of Mecca the story of Prophet Hud, who was from the people of 'Ad, when he warned his people residing in Ahqaf about the torment of God. Allah explained that sending messengers and prophets to their respective people is a common occurrence and has become *sunnatullah* (Allah's established way).

Before Prophet Hud, Allah had sent messengers and prophets who gave warnings to their respective people, and so too after him. Prophet Hud called upon his people not to worship except Allah, the One God, who created them, who provides sustenance so that they can live with that sustenance and maintain their lives. They should fear the calamity that will befall them later as a result of their disobedience. In the Hereafter, they will receive a painful torment.

The state of affairs on the Day of Judgment is explained in Allah's words:

"Indeed, the Day of Decision is the appointed time for them all - The Day when no friend will avail a friend at all, nor will they be helped." (ad-Dukhan/44: 40-41)

Al-Ahqaf means "sand dunes." Then that name was made the name of a region located between the land of Oman and Mahrah. The region was named that by the people of 'Ad. Now the region is known as "Sahara al-Ahqaf," and it is one of the regions that is part of the southern region of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia. It is located north of Hadramaut, bounded on the east by the Sea of Yemen, and on the south by Nejed.

Initially, the people of 'Ad adhered to a religion based on *tauhid* (monotheism). After several generations passed, elements of *shirk* (polytheism) entered the *tauhid* belief, starting with honoring their deceased leaders and heroes by making statues of them. Over time, this giving of honor turned into giving honor to statues, which eventually turned into worship of deities, meaning that they considered their deceased leaders and heroes as gods. To return them to the true religion, which is the religion of *tauhid*, Allah sent a messenger who was appointed from their own family, namely Prophet Hud. Hud called upon them to return to the true belief, which is the belief in *tauhid*, by worshiping only Allah alone, no longer associating partners with Him in the form of other gods.
text.22:
When the Prophet Hud called his people to believe, the people of 'Ad answered that call by saying, "Have you been sent to us to turn us away from the religion of our forefathers so that we no longer worship our gods and only worship your God?" They asked Hud to prove his prophethood by immediately bringing the punishment that had been promised to them, if they did not believe. In another verse, they even accused Hud of being insane. Allah says:

"We only say that some of our gods have afflicted you with madness." (Hud/11: 54)
text.23:
In this verse, the answer of Prophet Hud to the challenge of the disbelievers is explained, regarding the hastening of the punishment that had been promised to them if they did not believe. Prophet Hud answered that only Allah knows when the threatened punishment will come. Prophet Hud himself also did not know when the punishment would come. The duty of the prophet is only to convey the message from Allah.

The people of 'Ad should have been grateful that one of their own people was sent as a prophet to give warnings, information about the law, the fundamentals of faith ('aqidah), and the correct ways of worship. All of this was conveyed because of the command of Allah, the Lord, the Creator of all things.

Without guidance from Allah, no one knows the true essence of the correct religion. Humans do not know which God truly deserves to be worshipped and who has the right to determine how to worship correctly. Therefore, it is natural if there are people who do not understand all things, because the human mind is indeed limited. This is where the necessity of Allah sending prophets and messengers lies, and humans must strive to understand and believe in them.
text.24:
Nabi Hud exerted every effort to invite his people to embrace the true religion. In other verses, it is explained that Nabi Hud challenged his people to collectively, along with their deities, confront and kill him. However, they ignored this challenge, leading Allah to decide to inflict punishment upon them.

The punishment began with a prolonged drought that struck their land. In this state, they saw dark clouds gathering in the sky and moving towards their territory. They were all delighted by the arrival of the clouds. They believed that the clouds were a sign of imminent rain, which they had been desperately hoping for. They said, "These are clouds that bring rain." Then Nabi Hud gazed at the clouds and observed them carefully, and then he said, "These gathering clouds are not a sign of the coming rain as you think, but rather a sign of the coming punishment that you desired and awaited. The punishment that will come to destroy you is a fierce wind that will annihilate you and everything it touches. It will destroy you and all your wealth and will destroy all the power of the deities you always boast about, according to the task that God has commanded it."

In another verse, the form of the punishment inflicted upon the people of 'Ad is explained. Allah says:

"And as for 'Ad, they were destroyed by a furious wind, exceedingly violent; He imposed it on them for seven nights and eight days in succession, so that you could see the people therein fallen (as if they were) hollow trunks of palm trees. Then do you see of them any remnant?" (al-haqqah/69: 6-8).

And the word of Allah:

"And in (the story of) 'Ad, when We sent against them the devastating wind. It spared nothing that it reached, but made it like ashes." (adh-dzariyat/51: 41-42)

The severity of the punishment inflicted upon the people of 'Ad is reflected in the attitude of the Prophet Muhammad saw when a strong wind blew. In a hadith, it is explained as follows:

'Aisha said, "When there was a strong wind blowing, the Messenger of Allah saw would pray, 'O Lord, I ask You for the best of the wind; the best of its contents and the best of what it carries, and I seek refuge in You from the worst of the wind; the worst of its contents and the worst of what it carries.' When the sky showed signs of rain, the face of the Messenger of Allah saw would change. He would pace back and forth, going in and out of the house, to the front and to the back. Then, when the rain had fallen, his heart would be at ease, and I asked him about it, and he replied, 'I do not know, perhaps it is like what the people of 'Ad said, 'This cloud is bringing rain to us.'" (Narrated by Muslim, at-Tirmidhi, and an-Nasa'i)

The Messenger of Allah also said as follows:

'Aisha said, "I never saw the Messenger of Allah saw laugh so hard that his uvula was visible. He only smiled, but when he saw clouds and wind, his expression would change. I asked him, 'O Messenger of Allah, I see people rejoice when they see clouds because they hope that the clouds will bring rain, but when I see you see clouds, I see a feeling of displeasure on your face.' The Messenger of Allah saw replied, 'O 'Aisha, who can guarantee that the clouds do not carry punishment? A people were once punished with that wind. Indeed, that people saw the punishment, but they thought it was clouds bringing rain, so they said, 'This cloud is coming to bring rain to us.'" (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)

In another hadith narrated by Muslim, it is explained:

Ibn 'Abbas explained that the Prophet saw once said, "I was helped by the east wind, and the people of 'Ad were destroyed by the west wind." (Narrated by Muslim)
text.25: In this verse, Allah warns the polytheists of Mecca that He inflicted a terrible torment upon the people of 'Ad. So terrible was the torment that whatever was struck by the torment, in the form of a bitterly cold wind that blew violently, was certainly destroyed. They died scattered. Houses and buildings collapsed, objects flew, trees fell. Nothing was visible anymore, except for ruins and their scattered dwellings. Such a torment also befell other peoples, such as the people of Thamud, the people of Lot, and the people of Shu'aib. All of them were people who disbelieved and disobeyed Allah. If the Quraysh persisted in disbelief, they would also be afflicted with such a torment.
text.26:
With this verse, Allah compares the state of the people of 'Ad who were destroyed with the polytheists of Mecca who were increasingly defiant towards the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), saying, "We had established the people of 'Ad in several aspects of worldly life. We have never established a people like We established them. We have given them abundant wealth, strong and powerful bodies, and the ability to form a state so that they could dominate the lands around them, but all of that could not save them from the punishment of Allah that was inflicted upon them." Allah says:

*Have they not traveled through the earth and seen what was the end of those before them? They were superior to them in strength and in the traces (they left) in the land, but all that they used to earn did not avail them.* (Ghafir/40: 82)

Furthermore, verse 26 explains that Allah had given many blessings to the people of 'Ad. Allah had given them a good place, bestowed good eyesight, and sharp hearing so that they could pay attention to the verses and signs of Allah's greatness. However, they did not use them, in fact, they did not utilize them well and correctly.

History has proven that the people of 'Ad once had a high culture. They were able to organize a government and build a state. They built palaces, fortresses, mined minerals from the earth, and created canals to create regular irrigation. With regular irrigation, their land became fertile. They were also able to cultivate the land well so that they lived prosperously. In addition, they were also able to form a strong army so that their country became a leading country in the Arabian Peninsula at that time. Allah says:

*Do you build on every high place a monument for amusement, and take for yourselves palaces and fortresses that you may abide?* (ash-Shu'ara'/26: 128-129)

The blessings and greatness that Allah had bestowed should have been food for thought for them about who had helped them achieve all that they aspired to. But all of that increased their arrogance and pride. They thought that this state of affairs was obtained solely through their ability and will, and that they would have it forever. Allah says:

*As for 'Ad, they were arrogant upon the earth without right and said, "Who is greater than us in strength?" Did they not consider that Allah who created them was greater than them in strength? And they were denying Our signs.* (Fussilat/41: 15)

Furthermore, Allah explains that the people of 'Ad could not benefit from all that had been bestowed upon them because they denied the call of the messenger who was sent to them and denied the miracles of the messenger. As a result, they were afflicted with the punishment that they always asked to be hastened, because according to them, the punishment was impossible to happen.
text.27:
Allah reminds the polytheists of Mecca to take a lesson from the bitter experiences of those who came before, who had denied the messengers sent to them. These people of the past lived not far from Mecca, such as the people of 'Ad in Ahqaf, and the people of Thamud who resided in the area between Mecca and Syria. To them were also explained the signs of Allah's oneness, power, and greatness, and His religion was conveyed. However, they ignored it, even denying and mocking the messengers. When the punishment befell them, none of those they worshipped could help them, even the lifeless idols they worshipped were destroyed along with them.

That was the falsehood and denial of the previous nations, and that was the recompense and punishment they received. From this verse, there is a threat from Allah to the polytheists of Mecca that they will surely be afflicted with punishment, as experienced by the people of 'Ad, Thamud, and other nations, if they continue to disregard the call of Muhammad ﷺ as the Messenger of Allah sent to them.
text.28:
Allah reminds the polytheists of Mecca to take a lesson from the bitter experiences that were suffered by those who came before, who had denied the messengers sent to them. Those people of the past lived not far from Mecca, such as the people of 'Ad in Ahqaf, and the people of Thamud who resided in the area between Mecca and Syria. To them, signs of Allah's oneness, power, and greatness had also been explained, and His religion had been conveyed. However, they ignored it, even denying and mocking the messengers. When the punishment befell them, none of those objects of worship could help them, even the lifeless idols were destroyed along with them.

That was the falsehood and denial of the previous communities, and that was the recompense and punishment they received. From this verse, there is a threat from Allah to the polytheists of Mecca that they will surely be afflicted with punishment, like that experienced by the people of 'Ad, Thamud, and other communities if they continue to disregard the call of Muhammad (saw) as the Messenger of Allah sent to them.
text.29:
In this verse, Allah commands the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) to convey to the polytheists of Mecca the event of his meeting with a group of jinn who came to him to listen to and pay attention to the recitation of the verses of the Qur'an. When they listened to his recitation, some of them said to others, "Listen carefully to this recitation of the Qur'an so that we can concentrate on the recitation that we have never heard before, and to show good manners and etiquette when listening to the recitation of this noble verse of the Qur'an." After they finished listening to the recitation of the Qur'an, they returned to their people to convey what they had heard.

This verse explains that the jinn listened to the recitation of the verses of the Qur'an from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). How the jinn listened to the recitation and how the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) made them hear it is not explained clearly. Likewise, there is no concrete evidence that can be presented with certainty about the existence of the realm of the jinn itself.

The existence of the realm of the jinn is only obtained from the verses of the Qur'an and the hadith of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). Therefore, we as Muslims are obliged to believe in the existence of the jinn, just as we are obliged to believe in the existence of angels, because belief in the existence of jinn and angels is included in faith in the entire contents of the Qur'an, which is the main source of the Islamic religion.

Angels and jinn are included among the unseen creatures, therefore only Allah knows for sure about their essence and creation. A Muslim is obliged to believe that the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) had contact with angels, such as when receiving revelation and so on. Likewise, a Muslim is also obliged to believe that at one time, when the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was still alive, he had contact with the jinn, namely when reciting the verses of the Qur'an to them, and when they listened attentively, then conveyed it to their people.

Regarding the hadith of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) which explains his meeting with a group of jinn, among others, is the hadith below:

Masruq said, "I asked Ibn Mas'ud about who informed the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) of the presence of the jinn on the night they listened to the recitation of the Qur'an," he replied, "The one who informed of their presence was the tree." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)

In another hadith, it is mentioned as follows:

'Alqamah said, "I asked Ibn Mas'ud, was there anyone among you who accompanied the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) on the night of his meeting with the jinn?" Ibn Mas'ud replied, "None of us accompanied him." (Narrated by Ahmad, Muslim, and at-Tirmidhi)

This verse was revealed when the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and his companions were facing very heavy challenges from the polytheists of Mecca. After his beloved wife, Khadijah, died, followed by the death of his uncle, Abu Talib, he felt the loss of those who had protected and helped him from the disturbances of the Quraysh. Meanwhile, the threats and disturbances of the Quraysh increased. Facing this kind of situation, he went to the city of Taif with the hope of getting protection and help from Bani Thaqif. But he did not get what he hoped for, even Bani Thaqif themselves acted harshly by ordering their slaves to drive away and pelt the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) so that his feet were injured and bleeding. They forced the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) to flee to the garden of 'Utbah and Shaybah. There he took shelter from the scorching sun. After he prayed for help from Allah, the slaves left. Then the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) returned to Mecca. On the way, he stopped at Nakhlah, a place on the outskirts of the city of Mecca. He spent the night there. So on the night when he was praying and reciting the Qur'an in that prayer, Allah mobilized seven leaders of the jinn to listen to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) reciting the Qur'an. He did not know about the arrival of the jinn and he also did not know when the jinn returned to their place. Only with the revelation of this verse did the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) know about the arrival of the jinn.

This verse was revealed to reassure the Prophet and his companions. Not long after that, the event of Isra' and Mi'raj took place. Both events strengthened the Prophet's heart and his conviction in the success of conveying the message that Allah had entrusted to him.

This verse also explains that the jinn paid attention to the verses of the Qur'an that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) recited, then conveyed the contents of the Qur'an to their people. From this event, it can be concluded that the call of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) is not only addressed to all humans, but also addressed to the jinn, unseen creatures whose essence and condition cannot be known by humans. It's just that we humans do not know when and how the jinn carry out Allah's commands and avoid His prohibitions.

Some scholars of tafsir conclude based on this verse that if there are living beings outside this planet, whose condition is like humans, namely able to think, act, and feel, then the message of Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) also applies to them, and Muslims are obliged to convey it to them as much as possible. The jinn as unseen creatures are obliged to carry out the message of Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and surely other creatures who are not unseen and are the same as humans are even more obliged to carry out the message of Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him).
text.30:
In this verse, it is explained that a group of jinn who had heard the recitation of the Qur'an from the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) called out to their people, "O our people, indeed we have heard a book revealed after Moses, confirming what was before it, guiding to the truth and to a straight path." This book confirms the books that Allah revealed previously, showing the best path for someone who wants to achieve happiness in this world and happiness in the hereafter, and explaining the path that is pleasing to Allah and the path that is not pleasing to Allah. Jinn are also creatures who must bear the obligation to worship. Allah says:

.

"And I did not create the jinn and mankind except to worship Me." (adh-dhariyat/51: 56)
text.31:
Furthermore, the jinn called out to their people, "O our people, respond and accept the call of Muhammad, peace be upon him, as the Messenger of Allah who has called mankind to follow the religion of Allah, to believe in Him so that Allah may forgive their sins and protect them from a punishment from which no one can escape, except with His permission." This verse provides the understanding that:

1. Although there are jinn who believe and others who disbelieve, in this verse they are called upon to believe in Allah.

2. The jinn are obligated to worship Allah. Therefore, the jinn receive the Sharia just as the Sharia is conveyed by the prophets and messengers to mankind.

3. The jinn who believe will be saved from the fire of Hell.
text.32:
Then it is explained in this verse that if there are among the jinn who reject the call of Muhammad as the Messenger of Allah, that is, do not carry out Allah's commands and distance themselves from His prohibitions mentioned in the Qur'an and hadith, then they cannot escape His punishment. They will not find a helper to release themselves from Allah's punishment, unless Allah Himself wills it.

From this verse, it can be understood that all the acts of worship that are obligatory for Muslims are also obligatory for all jinn to perform, such as prayer (salat), fasting, helping one another, and so on. It is also explained that the jinn who do not follow the call of Muhammad saw are in error and deviate from the right path.
text.33:
This verse is a stern rebuke to the disbelievers who deny the Day of Resurrection and the existence of life after death to account for the deeds that humans have done. Allah reproaches the disbelievers who are heedless and never contemplate the events of the universe, thus failing to realize that Allah, who created the heavens and the earth, never felt weary in that creation. Allah is also capable of resurrecting the dead.

From this verse, it is understood that the disbelievers never use their minds to contemplate the events of the universe in the true sense. They refuse to think about who created the universe, which is so orderly and equipped with very neat and solid laws. They also refuse to think about who created themselves and maintains their lives. If they were willing to think with the aim of seeking the truth, they would come to the conclusion that the creator of all that is Allah, the All-Wise, the All-Powerful. If He is All-Powerful, then surely He is able to carry out everything He wills, without feeling tired. A Being with such attributes would certainly find it easy to resurrect those whom He has caused to die, because creating the heavens and the earth is far more difficult than creating humans, causing them to die, and resurrecting them.

Allah says:

"The creation of the heavens and the earth is certainly greater than the creation of mankind, but most of mankind do not know." (Ghafir/40: 57)

Furthermore, usually recreating something is easier than creating it for the first time. Allah says:

"And He is the One Who originates the creation, then repeats it, and that is easier for Him. And to Him belongs the loftiest description in the heavens and the earth. And He is the Almighty, the All-Wise." (ar-Rum/30: 27)

At the end of this verse, it is emphasized that the Creator of all things, the Almighty, is Allah, the All-Powerful. He can do whatever He wills, without anyone being able to hinder or oppose Him.
text.34:
In this verse, Allah explains the consequences that will be received by those who deny the existence of the Day of Resurrection. On the Day of Resurrection, they and those who do not believe in the existence of Allah's reward and punishment will be cast into a blazing fire of Hell.

To the disbelievers, a painful and humiliating question will be addressed: "O disbelievers, is not the punishment you are experiencing today the punishment that you were warned about before, while you were alive in the world, but you denied and mocked it?" They will answer, "Indeed, our Lord, we have truly felt the consequences." Allah will say to them, "Now taste what you used to mock. This is a fitting recompense for your attitude and actions."
text.35:
In this verse, Allah commands Prophet Muhammad to remain steadfast in facing the attitudes and actions of the disbelievers who deny and reject the message conveyed to them, like the steadfastness and patience shown by the previous *ulul 'azmi* prophets. The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) carried out this command of Allah well. He was always patient and steadfast in facing all kinds of trials that came to him. Regarding his patience, it is explained in the hadith as follows:

From 'Aisyah, she said, "The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) always fasted, then his stomach became sunken, then he continued to fast, then his stomach became sunken, then he fasted. He said, 'O Aisyah, indeed worldly pleasures are not appropriate for Muhammad and his family. O Aisyah, indeed Allah does not like the *ulul 'azmi* prophets (Noah, Abraham, Moses, Jesus, and Muhammad) except to be patient with all their trials and patient with what they love, then Allah does not like me except that He burdens me with what He has burdened those prophets with. So He said, 'Be patient as the *ulul 'azmi* prophets have been patient. And indeed I, by Allah, will truly be patient like those prophets, and there is no power except the power of Allah.'" (Narrated by Ibn Abi Hatim and ad-Dailami)

Patience is a primary virtue and the key to success. Blessed are those who possess this quality. The opposite of patience is haste. In this verse, Allah condemns the characteristic of haste and warns Prophet Muhammad not to possess this trait, such as asking Allah to immediately inflict punishment on the polytheists who deny his call, because the punishment will surely befall them, and only Allah knows when it will come.

Allah says:

And leave Me to deal with the deniers, those of ease and luxury, and allow them respite for a little while. (al-Muzzammil/73: 11)

And the word of Allah:

So allow the disbelievers respite. Give them respite for a little while. (ath-Thariq/86: 17)

Next, Allah explains the condition of the disbelievers in the Hereafter when they see the punishment that will befall them. They feel as if they lived in this world only for a moment, during the day. This feeling arises because of the sin and fear that arise in their hearts when they see the punishment that will befall them. Their condition is explained by Allah in another verse when they are asked how long they lived in the world.

He (Allah) will say, "How long did you remain on earth in number of years?" They will say, "We remained a day or part of a day; ask those who enumerate." (al-Mu'minun/23: 112-113)

And the word of Allah:

On the Day they see it, it will be as though they had not remained [in the world] except for an afternoon or a morning. (an-Nazi'at/79: 46)

In this verse, there is the word "balag" which in this verse means "sufficient." The meaning is: Allah states that this verse is a sufficient explanation for mankind, especially the disbelievers who want to think and contemplate the events of this universe. If they do not want to heed this explanation, they will surely bear the consequences. In another verse, Allah says:

This [Qur'an] is a clear statement to [all] the people and a guidance and instruction for those conscious of Allah. (Ibrahim/14: 52)

And the word of Allah:

Indeed, in this [Qur'an] is notification for a people who worship [Allah]. (al-Anbiya'/21: 106)

At the end of this verse, Allah affirms that no matter how great and terrible Allah's punishment is, it will not befall those who believe and do good deeds. Only the disbelievers who do not heed Allah's commands and violate His prohibitions will be struck by that terrible punishment. This verse also illustrates how great Allah's mercy and grace are bestowed upon those who are obedient to Him. In connection with this mercy and grace, punishment and disaster, the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) often prayed to Allah, as mentioned in the hadith below:

"It is narrated from Anas that the Prophet (peace be upon him) prayed, "O Lord, indeed I ask You for the causes of Your mercy, the certainty of Your forgiveness, and good fortune from all goodness, and safety from every sinful deed. O Lord, do not leave a single sin for me except that You forgive it, and a distress except that You relieve it, and a debt except that You pay it, and likewise every need from the needs of this world and the Hereafter, except that You fulfill it with Your mercy, O Lord, the Most Merciful." (Narrated by ath-Thabrani)
